metadata.case_name: Hindustan Hosiery Industries v. Mill Mazdoor Sabha

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against award dated 29th January 1970 of Industrial Court, Maharashtra (Tribunal) in Reference IC No. 2 of 1969.
Reference by Mill Mazdoor Sabha (Sabha) under section 73A of Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, pursuant to notice of change dated 22nd August 1968.

Sabha demanded revised basic wages for time-rated workmen of several categories, rise of 50 in wage of piece-rated workers in CPI bracket 621-636 (old series), dearness allowance of 10 paise per day for every rise of 10 points or part thereof above said slab, retrospectively from 1st June 1968.
Sabha submitted statement of claim on 14th February 1969.
Appellant is partnership firm constituted and commenced production in April 1967, manufactures and sells nylon and hosiery goods, registered as small scale industry.
Prior to April 1967, partners were in Hindustan Hosiery Factory, constituted 15th December 1963 after dissolution of India Hosiery Factory on 14th December 1963.
On same date as dissolution, some partners constituted Stretchlon Private Ltd.
Hindustan Hosiery Factory closed August 1966; appellant commenced as Hindustan Hosiery Industries from 17th April 1967; another firm Hindustan Hosiery Mills also commenced same date.
All three firms (Stretchlon, appellant, Hindustan Hosiery Mills) offshoots of India Hosiery Factory with 800 workmen.
Sabha contended consolidated wages extremely low: time-rated Rs. 2.50 to 3.50 per day; piece-rated (skilled) Rs. 6-7 per day.

Appellant: new concern, employed some workers from Hindustan Hosiery Factory; piece-rated average Rs. 6 to 10.20 per day adequate for highly skilled jobs; wages higher than other concerns; only 2 years old, financial position unassessable; 250 workers; demands excessive.
Tribunal had Ext. C-2 (employees below Rs. 5/day), Ext. C-3 (others), books; observed many piece-rated Rs. 4.60/day, time-rated Rs. 2.50/day; wages inadequate even for loss-making concern.

Appellant started 17th April 1967; from Ext. U-1 (Sabha), profits Rs. 1,51,000 in 8 months 1967, Rs. 1,88,000 in 1968 (after depreciation, interest, bonus); capital Rs. 2,28,000 (1967), Rs. 3,42,000 (1968); sound financial position.
Appellant wanted Tribunal to follow William Industries wage scale (Ext. C-1); Tribunal rejected due to lack of financial details.

Sabha: appellant more prosperous than Stretchlon; cited Stretchlon award 10th April 1967 (gazette 11th May 1967); demand in 1966 within 3 years of Stretchlon start (1963); profits 1963-65 shown; other concerns paid higher despite losses; awarded Rs. 5/day minimum to lowest category in CPI 621-630.

Tribunal award: first 13 categories (lowest) Rs. 5/day in 621-630; 14-19 Rs. 5.50; 20-21 Rs. 7; 22 Rs. 7.50; 23 Rs. 8.50; DA 10 paise/10 points above; piece-rates +30 (not 50) in 621-630 + same DA; retrospective from 1st February 1969.
Settlement with Hindustan Hosiery Mills and Sabha: Re. 1/day increase for <=Rs.5/day, 50 paise for >Rs.5; additional burden Rs. 56,022/year; appellant prepared to allow.
Sabha written statement paras 5-6: wages excessively low, below absolute minimum in Bombay region, lower than comparable concerns; appellant can bear burden.
Appellant written statement para 5: cannot bear burden; consider ability and stability.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal erred in wage fixation by ignoring distinction between minimum wage and fair wage, capacity to pay, and relevant settlements.
Whether awarded wages constitute bare minimum or higher bordering fair wage.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal erred in ignoring difference between minimum wage and fair wage; granted fair wage without considering settled factors.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles from Express Newspapers Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal ignored capacity of appellant to bear additional burden.
Tribunal ought to have considered settlement with Hindustan Hosiery Mills.
No justification for increase higher than statutory minimum in other industries (Rs.90-128/month).

respondent_arguments.text: Tribunal awarded only minimum wage or lower than lowest fair wage level.
Materials from Stretchlon award and regional wage trends support increase; no industry can pay below minimum.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal considered case for wage higher than bare minimum bordering fair wage, using Stretchlon award as yardstick which sought fair minimum.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Yardstick of present award is Stretchlon award seeking fair wage.

court_reasoning.text: Discussed concepts: minimum wage (subsistence + efficiency, education, medical); fair wage (between min and living, considers capacity); statutory min may be higher.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minimum wage provides not merely bare sustenance but preservation of efficiency.

court_reasoning.text: Fair wage upper limit by industry capacity (present + future); varies with economy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fair wage lies between minimum and living wage.

court_reasoning.text: Wage structure balances social justice and profits; minimum irrespective of capacity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Industry unable to pay minimum has no right to exist.

court_reasoning.text: Minimum wage considers cost of living, neutralizes price rise via DA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Linking minimum wages to cost of living index not alien to concept.

court_reasoning.text: Fixation on industry-cum-region basis, regard to unit capacity; consider comparable concerns.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Take into account wage scales in comparable concerns.

court_reasoning.text: Piece rates: consider quantity, time rates correlation, skill, machine, incentive, no fatigue, guaranteed min; balance aspects.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Piece-rates must not drive to exhaustion; eye on time factor.

court_reasoning.text: Art.136 not appeal; intervene only for natural justice violation, grave injustice, important principle.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No arguments sufficient to interpose; Tribunal followed principles.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal took prevailing min rates in region, capacity; piece rates increased to avoid discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No showing wages unfair or unbearable.

holdings.text: Tribunal correctly fixed wages considering minimum/fair wage principles, regional rates, capacity; no intervention under Art.136.

precedents_cited.case_name: Express Newspapers Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Concepts of minimum, fair, living wage; minimum provides sustenance + efficiency + education/medical.

precedents_cited.case_name: Crown Aluminium Works v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Industry unable to pay bare minimum has no right to exist.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kamani Metals & Alloys Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Balance social justice and profits; minimum irrespective of capacity; fair wage related to earning capacity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hydro Engineers Pvt. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Minimum wage considers cost of living, DA linkage.
Minimum not bare physical needs; sustenance + efficiency.

precedents_cited.case_name: U. Unichoyi v. State of Kerala
Renault Chemical and Pharmaceutical Works Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.136 discretion: only for grave injustice, important principle.
Wage fixation benchmark for comparable firm.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No fixed minimum for this industry; compared to other industries' statutory minima.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave appeal; discretionary jurisdiction limits.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Tribunal's award upheld as it properly considered wage principles, regional rates, capacity to pay, and avoided discrimination between worker categories.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; Tribunal award confirmed.

key_quotes.text: "If an industry is unable to pay to its workmen atleast bare minimum wage it has no right to exist."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle for minimum wage irrespective of capacity.

key_quotes.text: "The fair wage is thus a mean between the living wage and the minimum wage."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "None of the arguments raised by the appellant should be sufficient to persuade the Court to interpose relief in its favour."
key_quotes.speaker: court
